configPara1: The config.json file has two sections. The first section contains the settings for the overall structure of your project. The second section includes a question generator for (optional) questionnaires before and/or after the participant completes the Q sort.
configPara2: If you have a config.xml file from another Quincy project made with this version of the configurator, you can load its data for editing by clicking the orange - Load 'config.json' File Data - button below. If you don't have a file from a previous project, you can load the default config.xml file from the settings folder, or you can create a new file by inputting all of the data yourself.
configPara3: After you have added your data, click the orange button at the bottom of the page to save the information as 'config.json' in the settings folder (replacing the default file).
projectLinking: Link to a Second Q Sort
sortImages: Sort Images / Pictures Instead of Text Statements
imageSortDisabled: Image is currently unavailable, but will be restored in a future release.
areYouSure: Are you sure you want to delete this item?
enterOrPasteStatements: Enter or Paste Statements (1 statement per line)
loadStatements: Load statements.xml File (from a previous project)
saveStatements: Save New or Modified Statements File (replacing the default file)
toChangeTheDatabase: The database selection is determined by the config.xml file. To change databases, reload the config.xml file and make the desired change.
illustratedSetupGuideForBaserowDatabase: Illustrated Setup Guide for Data Storage
databaseIntroText: {{{b}}}Baserow{{{/b}}} is a free and open-source online database platform that allows you to create and manage databases without any coding knowledge. It provides a user-friendly interface for creating tables, adding fields, and managing data. Baserow also offers an API that can be used to connect your Quincy project to the database.
baserowStep1: Create a new user account on Baserow by clicking on the 'Sign Up' button in the upper right corner of the page.
baserowStep2: Next, fill in the required information and click the 'Get Started' button.
baserowStep3: Click the 'Skip for now' button to bypass the data collection.
baserowStep4: Click the 'Skip for now' button to bypass the data collection.
baserowStep5: Input your first workspace name (any name is fine) and click the 'Continue' button.
baserowStep6: Click the 'Skip for now' button to skip inviting collaborators.
baserowStep7: Input your database name and click the 'Continue' button.
baserowStep8: Click the '+Add your own' button to add your database table.
baserowStep9: Input your table name and what it includes, then click the 'Continue' button.
baserowStep10: Click the 'Date' button and then click 'Continue'.
emailOnlyDescription: No database setup is needed for this option. The participant' default email client will send the data by email to the researcher.
baserowStep11: The Baserow screen will show a grid with 'Name' and 'Date' columns.
baserowStep14: Click the display icon next to the database name.
baserowStep16: Click on the 'Database tokens' link, then click 'Create token'.
baserowStep17: Enter a name for the token and set the 'Workspace' to your database.
baserowStep19: Click on the 'show databases button' and then deactivate the 'read', 'update', and 'delete' options (see image below).
firebaseStep1: First, create a new user account on firebase.google.com by clicking on the 'Get Sign in' button in the upper right corner of the page.
firebaseStep2: Next, create a Google account if you don't have one already, or sign in.
firebaseStep3: Once you have created your Firebase account, in the main dashboard Click the 'Create a project' button start the setup process.
firebaseStep4: Input your project name and click the 'Continue' button.
firebaseStep5: Click the 'Continue' button on the AI Assistance screen.
firebaseStep6: Click the 'Enable Google Analytics for the project' switch to off, and then click the 'Create project' button.
firebaseStep7: Click the 'Cloud Firestore' button in the left-hand menu.
firebaseStep8: Click the 'Start Collection' button to create a new collection.
firebaseStep9: Input your collection ID and click the 'Next' button.
firebaseStep10: Click the 'Auto ID' button and then click the 'Save' button.
firebaseStep11: Click the 'Rules' tab and change the rules to the following:
firebaseStep12: Click the 'Publish' button to save the rules.
firebaseStep13: Click the 'Project Overview' button in the left-hand menu.
firebaseStep14: Click the 'Web' button to add Firebase to your web app.
firebaseStep15: Input your app nickname and click the 'Register App' button.
firebaseStep16: Copy the Firebase SDK snippet and paste it into the 'firebaseConfig' section of the config.json file.
firebaseStep18: Click the 'Authentication' button in the left-hand menu.
firebaseStep19: Click the 'Get Started' button to set up authentication.
firebaseStep20: Click the 'Email/Password' button and then click the 'Enable' button.
firebaseStep21: Click the 'Database' button in the left-hand menu.
firebaseStep22: Click the 'Create Database' button to create a new database.
firebaseStep23: Select 'Start in test mode' and click the 'Next' button.
firebaseStep24: Click the 'Done' button to create the database.
